{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox Minister | name =António Monteiro | image = | imagesize = | caption = | office = [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Portugal)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] | primeminister = | predecessor = [[Teresa Patrício Gouveia]] | successor = [[Diogo Freitas do Amaral]] | term_start = 17 July 2004 | term_end = 12 March 2005 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1944|1|22}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = | residence = | alma_mater =[[University of Lisbon]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] | religion= | children = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''António Vitor Martins Monteiro''' (born 22 January 1944) is a Portuguese diplomat who served as [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Portugal)|the minister of foreign affairs]] from 2004 to 2005.
==Early life and education== Monteiro was born in [[Angola]] on 22 January 1944.<ref name=unbio>{{cite web|title=Biographical note of Ambassador António Monteiro |url=http://www.un.int/portugal/bioAMonteiro.htm |publisher=UN |accessdate=16 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106030448/http://www.un.int/portugal/bioAMonteiro.htm |archivedate=6 January 2010 }}</ref> He received a degree in law from [[University of Lisbon|the University of Lisbon]] in 1967.<ref>{{cite web|title=SOCO insider: Antonio Monteiro|url=http://www.macroaxis.com/invest/manager/SIA.L--Antonio_Monteiro|publisher=SOCO|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref>
==Career== Monteiro began his career at [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Portugal)|the ministry of foreign affairs]] in 1968.<ref name=fmillennium/> He worked at Portuguese embassies in [[the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] (1971) and [[Italy]] (1976) and served as permanent representative of Portugal to the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] and alternate governor to the [[International Fund for Agricultural Development]] in [[Rome]].<ref name=unbio/> In addition, he was deputy permanent representative at the Permanent Mission of Portugal to [[the United Nations]] from 1981 to 1987.<ref name=un05/> Then he served at the ministry of foreign affairs in various capacities.<ref name=un05>{{cite web|title=United Nations Secretary-General appoints António Monteiro of Portugal as High Representative for the elections in Côte d’Ivoire|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2005/sga930.doc.htm|publisher=UN|accessdate=16 June 2013|date=15 July 2005}}</ref> He was appointed coordinator of the committee for permanent coordination of the community of Portuguese-Speaking countries in 1994 and served in office until 1996.<ref name=un05/> He was also the head of the temporary mission for the peace process structures in [[Angola]] and a representative to the joint political and military commission.<ref name=un05/> He headed the security council committee formed by Security Council resolution 661 (dated 1990) about the conflict between [[Iraq]] and [[Kuwait]].<ref name=socoint/> Then he served as the permanent representative of Portugal to the United Nations from January 1997 to March 2001, representing Portugal on [[Security Council|the Security Council]] during its membership in 1997 and 1998.<ref name=unbio/> He was the ambassador of Portugal to [[France]] from March 2001 to July 2004.<ref name=un05/>
He was appointed minister of foreign affairs on 17 July 2004, replacing [[Teresa Patrício Gouveia]] in the post.<ref name=rulers>{{cite web|title=Portuguese ministries (Foreign affairs)|url=http://www.rulers.org/portgov.html|publisher=Rulers|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> Monteiro's term lasted until 12 March 2005 and he was succeeded by [[Diogo Freitas do Amaral]].<ref name=rulers/> Monteiro was appointed by the then United Nations Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] as high representative of the United Nations for the elections in [[Côte d’Ivoire]] on 15 July 2005.<ref name=un3>{{cite web|title=Portugal at the United Nations |url=http://www.un.int/portugal/atun.html |publisher=UN |accessdate=16 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423151321/http://www.un.int/portugal/atun.html |archivedate=23 April 2009 }}</ref> From 2006 to 2009, he again served as ambassador of Portugal to France.<ref name=fmillennium/> In 2009, Monteiro began to work in private sector.<ref name=socoint>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.socointernational.co.uk/board-of-directors|publisher=Soco International|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> In September 2010, he was appointed by then UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] as a member to a UN panel tasked with monitoring [[South Sudanese independence referendum, 2011|the referendum]] that was held in [[Sudan]] in 2011.<ref name=uganda27sept>{{cite news|title=Mkapa to monitor Sudan referendum|url=http://www.ugandacorrespondent.com/articles/2010/09/mkapa-to-monitor-sudan-referendum/|accessdate=16 June 2013|newspaper=Uganda Correspondent|date=27 September 2010}}</ref> On 28 February 2012, he became chairman of the board of directors of Fundaçao Millennium company.<ref name=fmillennium>{{cite web|title=António Monteiro CV|url=http://ind.millenniumbcp.pt/en/Institucional/governacao/Documents/mod_organizacional/CV_Antonio_Monteiro_EN.pdf|publisher=Fundaçao Millennium company|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Monteiro, Antonio}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Portugal to France]] [[Category:Foreign ministers of Portugal]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Permanent Representatives of Portugal to the United Nations]] [[Category:Portuguese diplomats]] [[Category:Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Lisbon alumni]]

revision.text:
'''Asymmetric competition''' refers to forms of [[business]] competition where are considered competitors in some markets or contexts but not in others.<ref>DeSarbo, Wayne S., Rajdeep Grewal, and Jerry Wind. "Who competes with whom? A demand‐based perspective for identifying and representing asymmetric competition." Strategic Management Journal 27, no. 2 (2006): 101-129.</ref> In such cases a firm may choose to allocate competitive resources and marketing actions among its competitors out of proportion to their [[market share]].<ref>Carpenter, Gregory S., Lee G. Cooper, Dominique M. Hanssens, and David F. Midgley. "Modeling asymmetric competition." Marketing Science 7, no. 4 (1988): 393-412.</ref><ref>Gonzalez-Benito, Oscar, Pablo A. Munoz-Gallego, and Praveen K. Kopalle. "Asymmetric competition in retail store formats: Evaluating inter-and intra-format spatial effects." Journal of Retailing 81, no. 1 (2005): 59-73.</ref><ref>Heath, Timothy B., Gangseog Ryu, Subimal Chatterjee, Michael S. McCarthy, David L. Mothersbaugh, Sandra Milberg, and Gary J. Gaeth. "Asymmetric competition in choice and the leveraging of competitive disadvantages." Journal of Consumer Research 27, no. 3 (2000): 291-308.</ref><ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenwunker/2011/09/28/the-jeff-bezos-formula-for-asymmetric-competition/#7850899475ed</ref> Asymmetric competition can be visualized using techniques such as [[multidimensional scaling]] and [[perceptual mapping]].
==Forms of asymmetric competition== *Firm A may compete with B in some markets but not others. *Firm A competes with B over certain attributes (such as [[reliability engineering|reliability]] and [[design]]) but not over others (price). *Firm A considers B as a competitor but B does not consider A to be a competitor. *Firm A does not consider B to be a competitor, however, [[consumers]] see A's products as competing with B's products.
==See also== *[[Competition]] *[[Coopetition]] *[[Product differentiation]] *[[Non-price competition]] *[[Information asymmetry]] *[[Multimarket contact]] *[[Size-asymmetric competition]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Carpenter, Gregory S., Lee G. Cooper, Dominique M. Hanssens, and David F. Midgley. "Modeling asymmetric competition." Marketing Science 7, no. 4 (1988): 393-412. *[[Tibor Scitovsky|Scitovsky, Tibor]]. "The benefits of asymmetric markets." The Journal of Economic Perspectives 4, no. 1 (1990): 135-148. *[[Wayne DeSarbo|DeSarbo, Wayne S.]], [[Rajdeep Grewal]], and [[Jerry (Yoram) Wind|Jerry Wind]]. "Who competes with whom? A demand‐based perspective for identifying and representing asymmetric competition." Strategic Management Journal 27, no. 2 (2006): 101-129. *Etzion, Hila, and Edieal J. Pinker. "Asymmetric competition in B2B spot markets." Production and Operations Management 17, no. 2 (2008): 150-161. *Ringel, Daniel M., and Bernd Skiera. "Visualizing asymmetric competition among more than 1,000 products using big search data." Marketing Science 35, no. 3 (2016): 511-534.
[[Category:Marketing]] [[Category:Marketing research]] [[Category:Marketing strategy]]

revision.text:
'''BA 9000''' Body Armor Quality Management System Requirements were established by the [[National Institute of Justice]] as a quality standard for [[Personal armor|body armor]]. It specifies the construction and assembly requirements of personal armor for federal, state, tribal and local [[law enforcement]] and [[corrections]] agencies; the requirements of BA 9000 are voluntary (but it is recommended by the NIJ).
Though BA 9000 was written to be in compliance with [[ISO 9001]], the NIJ notes that a company being certified as ISO 9001 is not necessarily certified as being BA 9000-compliant.<ref name="BA 9000: National Institute of Justice Body Armor Quality Management System Requirements">{{Cite web |url= https://www.justnet.org/pdf/BA-9000-January-2012.pdf|publisher= National Institute of Justice |title= BA 9000: National Institute of Justice Body Armor Quality Management System Requirements|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref> BA 9000 incorporates all of the standards of ISO 9001, but it also:
* Details the procedures body armor manufacturers need to take to communication with the compliance testing program * Ensures the accountability of armor by mandating a unique identifier for each piece used * Management of work areas to reduce any adverse effects on the armor * Specifies that testing must be done at approved facilities; these facilities must be complaint with [[ISO 17025]]<ref name="BA 9000">{{Cite web |url=http://www.pjr.com/standards/ba-9000 |publisher= www.pjr.com|title= BA 9000|accessdate=July 23, 2014}}</ref>
While certification to BA 9000 is not mandated or regulatory, its benefits include: * Reduced Testing – For manufacturers who are BA 9000 certified, testing frequency can be reduced by half. * Competitive Advantage – Certification to a standard such as BA 9000 is an indicator of a quality product. This is a great advantage in an industry where quality could be the difference between life and death.<ref name="BA 9000"/>
Facilities seeking to become a BA 9000 certification body must, in addition to being ISO 17025-certified, submit to yearly office and an overall audit of the management systems in place. The accreditation is normally for a period of four years.<ref name="How to Become an ANAB-Accredited Certification Body">{{Cite web|url=http://www.anab.org/certification-bodies/become-a-certification-body.aspx |publisher=anab.org |title=How to Become an ANAB-Accredited Certification Body |accessdate=July 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729014525/http://www.anab.org/certification-bodies/become-a-certification-body.aspx |archivedate=July 29, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.justnet.org/pdf/BA-9000-January-2012.pdf/ BA 9000: National Institute of Justice Body Armor Quality Management System Requirements]
[[Category:United States Department of Justice]] [[Category:Body armor]] [[Category:Quality management]] [[Category:Quality]]

{{Infobox business park | name = Bishop Ranch | image = Bishop Ranch Logo.png | image_size = | caption = | location = [[San Ramon, California|San Ramon]], [[California]], [[United States]] | address = 2600 Camino Ramon, Suite 201, San Ramon, CA 94583 | coordinates = {{coord|37.7684433|-121.9702906}} | opening_date = 1978 | developer = Sunset Development Company | number_of_tenants = 550 | number_of_workers = 30,000 | website = {{URL|www.bishopranch.com}} }}
'''Bishop Ranch''' is a large [[business park]] in [[San Ramon, California|San Ramon]], [[California]]. Tenants include [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]], [[Bank of the West]], [[Pacific Gas and Electric Company|PG&E]], [[Ford Motor Company]], [[SAP SE|SAP]], [[General Electric]], and [[JPMorgan Chase]].
Bishop Ranch and the [[East Bay Regional Park District]]'s [[Bishop Ranch Regional Preserve]] were originally part of a 3,000-acre parcel of land called Norris Ranch. [[Western Electric]] acquired Bishop Ranch in 1955 to house a manufacturing plant. Sunset Development Company purchased the 585-acre parcel from Western Electric in 1978. In 2003, [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] moved its international headquarters to Bishop Ranch.
The city of San Ramon is planning a new 40-acre downtown that will include a public plaza, hotel, independent cinema and a mix of residential units plus a new city hall, library, transit center and office space, to be developed by Sunset Development Company.
==External links== [http://www.bishopranch.com/ Bishop Ranch]
[[Category:Business parks of the United States]] [[Category:San Ramon, California| ]]

revision.text:
{{about|the committee of the United Kingdom Privy Council|the more general article on business networks|Chamber of commerce|other uses|Board of Trade (disambiguation)}} [[Image:The Board of Trade.jpg|thumb|The Board of Trade circa 1808.]] The '''Board of Trade''' is a British government department concerned with commerce and industry, currently within the [[Department for International Trade]].<ref>[https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/board_of_trade]</ref> Its full title is '''The Lords of the Committee of the Privy Council appointed for the consideration of all matters relating to Trade and Foreign Plantations''', but is commonly known as the '''Board of Trade''', and formerly known as the '''Lords of Trade and Plantations''' or '''Lords of Trade''', is a committee of the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council of the United Kingdom]]. It was first established as a temporary committee of England's Privy Council to advise on colonial ([[Plantation (settlement or colony)|plantation]]) questions in the early 17th century, when [[English overseas possessions|these settlements]] were initially forming. The Board would evolve gradually into a government department with considerable power and a diverse range of functions,<ref name="BoT&Va">{{cite web|last1=Olson|first1=Alison G.|title=The Board of Trade and Colonial Virginia|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Board_of_Trade|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Virginia]]|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> including regulation of domestic and foreign commerce, the development, implementation and interpretation of the [[Navigation Acts|Acts of Trade and Navigation]], and the review and acceptance of legislation passed in the colonies. Between 1696 and 1782 the Board of Trade, in partnership with the various<ref>See: [[Secretary of State (England)]] (to 1660) [[Secretary of State for the Southern Department]] (1660-1768) [[Secretary of State for the Colonies]] (1768-1782)</ref> secretaries of state over that time, held responsible for colonial affairs, particularly in [[British America]]. The newly created office of [[Home Secretary]] then held colonial responsibility until 1801, when the [[Secretary of State for War and the Colonies]] was established.<ref>[http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C4196 Board of Trade and Secretaries of State: America and West Indies, Original Correspondence], The National Archives</ref><ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/records/research-guides/american-west-indian-colonies.htm American and West Indian colonies before 1782], The National Archives</ref>
Between 1768 and 1782 while with the [[Secretary of State for the Colonies]], whose secretaryship was held jointly with the presidency of the Board of Trade, the latter position remained largely vacant; this led to a diminished status of the board and it became an adjunct to the new Department and Ministry concerns. Following the loss of the [[American War of Independence]], both the board and the short-lived secretaryship were dismissed by the king on 2 May 1782 and the board was abolished later by the [[Civil List and Secret Service Money Act 1782]] (22 Geo. III, c 82).<ref name="BHO3">[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/office-holders/vol3/pp28-37#fnn3 Council of trade and plantations 1696-1782], in Office-Holders in Modern Britain: Volume 3, Officials of the Boards of Trade 1660-1870, p.28-37. University of London, London, 1974.</ref>
Following the [[Treaty of Paris 1783]], with the continuing need to regulate trade between its remaining colonies, the independent United States and all other countries, a new Committee of Council on Trade and Plantations (later known as 'the First Committee') was established by [[William Pitt the Younger]]. Initially mandated by an [[order in Council]] on 5 March 1784, the committee was reconstructed and strengthened by a second order, on 23 August 1786, under which it operated for the rest of its existence. The committee has been known as the Board of Trade since 1786, but this name was only officially adopted by an act of 1861. The new Board's first functions were consultative like earlier iterations, and its concern with plantations, in matters such as the approval of colonial laws, more successfully accomplished. As the industrial revolution expanded, the board's work became increasingly executive and domestic and from the 1840s a succession of acts of parliament gave it regulatory duties, notably concerning railways, merchant shipping, and joint stock companies.<ref>[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100915133842/http://nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/displaycataloguedetails.asp?CATLN=1&CATID=38&SearchInit=4&SearchType=6&CATREF=BT Records of the Board of Trade and of successor and related bodies], Department code BT The National Archives</ref>
This department was merged with the [[Ministry of Technology]] in 1970, to form the [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]]. The Secretary of State for Trade and Industry (from 2009 [[Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills]]) was also President of the Board of Trade. The full Board has met only once since the mid-20th century, during commemorations of the bicentenary of the Board in 1986. In 2016, the role of President of the Board of Trade was transferred to the Secretary of State for International Trade.<ref>See https://www.gov.uk/government/ministers/secretary-of-state-for-international-trade</ref> The Board was reconstituted in October 2017.<ref>See https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-41586496</ref>
==Early history== In 1622, at the end of the Dutch [[Twelve Years' Truce]], [[James I of England|King James I]] directed the [[Privy Council of England]] to establish a temporary committee to investigate the causes of various economic and supply problems, the decline in trade and consequent financial difficulties; detailed instructions and questions were given, with answers to be given "as fast as the several points shall be duly considered by you."<ref>[[Adam Anderson (economist)|Adam Anderson]], [https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=chpPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA294&#v=onepage&q&f=false An historical and chronological deduction of the origin of commerce: from the earliest accounts. Containing an history of the great commercial interests of the British Empire...], Vol. 2, p.294–297 (1787)</ref> This would be followed by a number of temporary committees and councils to regulate the colonies and their commerce.<ref name="BrCofT&P">[[Charles M. Andrews]], [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/33313/33313.txt British Committees, Commissions and Councils of Trade and Plantations 1622-1675],(1908)</ref> The Board's formal title remains "The Lords of the Committee of the Privy Council appointed for the consideration of all matters relating to Trade and Foreign Plantations".
In 1634, [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] appointed a new commission for regulating plantations.<ref>[http://avalon.law.yale.edu/17th_century/charter_005.asp **Royal Commission for Regulating Plantations; April 28, 1634]</ref> It was headed by the Archbishop of Canterbury with its primary goals to increase royal authority and the influence of the Church of England in the colonies, particularly with the great influx of Puritans to the New World. Soon after however, the [[English Civil War]]s erupted and initiated a long period of political instability in England and the resultant loss of productivity for these committees.<ref name="BoT&Va"/> Between 1643 and 1648 the [[Long Parliament]] would establish a parliamentary Commission for Plantations to take the lead in colonial and commercial affairs.<ref name="BrCofT&P"/> This period also saw the first regulation of Royal [[tonnage and poundage]] and begin the modernization of [[HM Customs and Excise|customs and excise]] as growing sources of government revenue.
During the [[Interregnum (England)|Interregnum]] and [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]] three acts of the [[Rump Parliament]] in 1650 and 1651 are notable in the historical development of England's commercial and colonial programs. These include the first Commission of Trade to be established by an Act of Parliament on 1 August 1650.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/no-series/acts-ordinances-interregnum/pp403-406 August 1650: An Act for the Advancing and Regulating of the Trade of this Commonwealth.]</ref> The instructions to the named commissioners, headed by [[Henry Vane the Younger]], included consideration of both domestic and foreign trade, the trading companies, manufactures, free ports, customs, excise, statistics, coinage and exchange, and fisheries, as well as the plantations and the best means of promoting their welfare and rendering them useful to England. The act's statesmanlike and comprehensive instructions, along with an October act [[An Act for prohibiting Trade with the Barbadoes, Virginia, Bermuda and Antego|prohibiting trade with pro-royalist colonies]] and the Navigation Act of October 1651, formed the first definitive expression of England's commercial policy. They represent the first attempt to establish a legitimate control of commercial and colonial affairs, and the instructions indicate the beginnings of a policy which had the prosperity and wealth of England exclusively at heart.<ref>Charles M. Andrews, [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/33313/33313.txt British Committees, Commissions and Councils of Trade and Plantations 1622-1675], Chapter II, Control of Trade and Plantations During the Interregnum, p.24 (1908)</ref>
It was the Lords of Trade who, in 1675, originated the idea of transforming all of the colonies in America into Royal Colonies for the purpose of securing English trade against the French. They brought New Hampshire under the Crown, modified Penn's charter, refused a charter to the Plymouth colony, and taking advantage of the concessions of the charters of Massachusetts and New York, created the [[Dominion of New England]] in 1685, thereby transforming all the territory from the [[Kennebec River|Kennebec]] to the [[Delaware River|Delaware]] into a single crown colony.<ref>{{cite book|last=Andrews|first=Charles M.|title=The Colonial Background of the American Revolution|year=1958|origyear=1924|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|location=New Haven and London|pages=11–12|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_colonial_background_of_the_American.html?id=QKlWAAAAYAAJ}}</ref>
In 1696, [[William III of England|King William III]] appointed eight paid commissioners to promote trade in the [[British America|American plantation]]s and elsewhere. The Lords Commissioners of Trade and Foreign Plantations, appointed in 1696 and commonly known as the Lords of Trade, did not constitute a committee of the Privy Council, but were, in fact, members of a separate body. The board carried on this work but also had long periods of inactivity, devolving into chaos after 1761 and dissolved in 1782 by an [[act of Parliament]] by the [[Rockingham Whigs]].
==Reestablishment and later history== [[William Pitt the Younger]] re-established the committee in 1784, and an [[Order in Council]] of 23 August 1786 provided the formal basis that still remains in force. A secretariat was established which included the president, vice president and board members. By 1793, the board still remained in its old structure, with 20 members including the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]].<ref name = Emsley9>Emsley 9</ref> After 1820 the board ceased to meet regularly and the business was carried out entirely by the secretariat. The short name of "Board of Trade" was formalised in 1861.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/24-25/47/section/65 Harbours and Passing Tolls, &c. Act 1861, section 65.]</ref>
In the 19th century the board had an advisory function on economic activity in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and its [[British Empire|empire]]. During the second half of the 19th century it also dealt with legislation for patents, designs and trade marks, company regulation, labour and factories, merchant shipping, agriculture, transport, power etc. Colonial matters passed to the [[Secretary of State for the Colonies|Colonial Office]] and other functions were devolved to newly created departments, a process that continued for much of the 20th century.
The original commission comprised the seven (later eight) [[Great Officer of State|Great Officers of State]], who were not required to attend meetings, and the eight paid members, who were required to attend. The Board, so constituted, had little real power, and matters related to trade and the colonies were usually within the jurisdiction of the [[Secretary of State|Secretaries of State]] and the Privy Council, with the Board confining itself mainly to colonial administration.
==Ministers== * [[President of the Board of Trade]] * [[Vice-President of the Board of Trade]] * [[Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade]]
==See also== *[[Imperial Lighthouse Service]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Works cited== *{{cite book| title = British Society and the French Wars 1793-1815| first = Clive| last = Emsley| year = 1979| publisher= Macmillan Press}} * Root, Winfred T. “The Lords of Trade and Plantations, 1675-1696.” ''American Historical Review'' 23 (October 1917): 20-41. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090609155119/http://www.berr.gov.uk/aboutus/corporate/history/outlines/BT-1621-1970/page13919.html History of the Board of Trade]
==External links== *[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=16802 Officials 1696-1782] *[http://www.boardoftrade.uk/ Private Sector UK Board of Trade Website] {{Privy Council (United Kingdom)}}

{{COI|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Bob Beers |office = Member of the [[Las Vegas City Council]]
from the 2nd ward |term_start = April 4, 2012 |term_end = July 19, 2017 |predecessor = Steven Wolfson |successor = Steve Seroka |state_senate1 = Nevada |district1 = 6th |term_start1 = 2004 |term_end1 = 2008 |predecessor1 = Ray Rawson |successor1 = [[Allison Copening]] |state_assembly2 = Nevada |district2 = 4th |term_start2 = 1998 |term_end2 = 2004 |predecessor2 = Deanna Braunlin |successor2 = Frances Allen |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|10|14}} |birth_place = [[Livermore, California]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] {{small|(Before 1989)}}
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] {{small|(1989–present)}} |spouse = Sarah Beers |education = [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]]) }} '''Robert T. Beers''' (born October 14, 1959) is an American accountant (CPA) and member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] who is a 2018 candidate for Nevada Treasurer. He was previously an elected member of the [[Las Vegas City Council]] from 2012 to 2017, [[Nevada Assembly]] from 1998 to 2004 and the [[Nevada Senate]] from 2005 to 2008. He ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for [[Governor of Nevada]] in [[Nevada gubernatorial election, 2006|2006]] and in January 2014, he announced that he would run against [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Senator [[Harry Reid]] in the [[United States Senate election in Nevada, 2016|2016 U.S. Senate election]],John L. Smith. "[http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/john-l-smith/las-vegas-city-councilman-beers-gets-early-start-against-harry-reid Beers Gets Early Start Against Reid]". Las Vegas Review Journal. Jan 31, 2014. Date Retrieved: Feb 9, 2014 but he withdrew from the race in June 2015. ==Early and personal life== Beers moved to Las Vegas at age 11, graduating from [[Ed W. Clark High School]] with high honors in 1977 and from the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] with distinction with a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration degree in 1987.[http://www.lasvegasnevada.gov/Government/councilman_beers.htm City of Las Vegas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140901083244/http://www.lasvegasnevada.gov/Government/councilman_beers.htm|date=September 1, 2014 }} Bob Beers His community activities include: current volunteer treasurer for the Old Spanish Trail Association, with past treasurer service to Southern Nevada Clean Communities, the Tonopah Historic Mining Park Foundation, and the Nevada Republican Party; president of the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce Business Expo; and President-elect for the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce Business Council. As a volunteer, he has created or maintained websites for over a dozen community organizations. ==Professional career== A [[Certified Public Accountant]] (CPA) since 1989, Beers founded Las Vegas computer accounting consultants Wilson, Beers & Alu in 1989, and sold it to a large local CPA firm in 2002. This company specialized in PC-based networks with multi-user accounting software. From 2004-2007, he was the marketing director for an outsourcer of HR. In 2009, he started Seale and Beers, CPAs, an auditor of small public companies, which he managed until 2012. He currently consults business owners on their treasuries. Before becoming a Certified Public Accountant, Beers worked for radio broadcasting companies in [[Reno, Nevada]] and Las Vegas as News Director. At [[KMJJ]] in 1982, he won "Best Miniseries" and "Best Newscast" awards from the Associated Press in the AP's Medium Market California-Nevada-Hawaii division.Desert Companion [http://www.desertcompanion.com/article.cfm?ArticleID=676 "What About Bob?"], desertcompanion.com; retrieved August 16, 2014. ==Political career== In 1998, Beers was elected to the [[Nevada Assembly]], the lower house of [[Nevada Legislature|Nevada's Legislature]]. As Assemblyman representing District 4, Beers served in three regular and three special sessions. He was assigned to the Ways & Means, Commerce & Labor, and Elections, Procedures & Ethics committees of the Assembly. In 2003, Beers led a group of legislators in opposition to Governor [[Kenny Guinn]]'s tax increases, citing concerns that they might damage Nevada's economy. After several special sessions, Beers' voting bloc failed and the tax increases were passed.Nevada Business [http://www.nevadabusiness.com/2003/08/black-thursday-supreme-court-judgement-day-threatens-nevadas-future "Editorial on Budget Battle"], nevadabusiness.com; retrieved August 15, 2014. The following year, Beers was elected to the Nevada Senate, defeating 20-year incumbent Republican Ray Rawson who had supported the increases.Nevada Secretary of State [http://www.nvsos.gov/SOSelectionPages/results/2004Primary/ElectionSummary.aspx "Official 2004 election results"] Retrieved 15 August 2014Ralston, Jon [http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2004/jul/15/rawson-beers-square-off "Ralston: reporting on Beers-Rawson debate"], ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'', July 15, 2004; retrieved August 15, 2014. Beers served in the [[Nevada Senate]] for the 2005 and 2007 Legislative sessions. He was appointed Vice-Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, where he worked on the complex state budget. He also served as a member of the Committees on Natural Resources and Legislative Operations. In 2006, Beers and his supporters gathered over 150,000 signatures to put a [[Taxpayer Bill of Rights]] amendment (called TASC for Tax And Spend Control) on the November 2006 general election ballot, which proposed that increases in spending greater than the sum of inflation and population growth require an affirmative vote of citizens.Las Vegas Sun [http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2006/jul/08/tasc-court-battle-looking-more-likely/ "TASC Court Battle Looking More Likely"] Retrieved August 16, 2014 He ran for [[Governor of Nevada]] in the [[Nevada gubernatorial election, 2006|2006 election]], but finished second in the Republican primary, behind U.S. Representative [[Jim Gibbons (U.S. politician)|Jim Gibbons]], who would go on to win the general election.{{cite web|url=http://www.nvsos.gov/SOSelectionPages/results/2006StateWidePrimary/ElectionSummary.aspx |title=nvsos.gov |publisher=nvsos.gov |date=2006-08-15 |accessdate=2013-04-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nvsos.gov/SOSelectionPages/results/2006StateWideGeneral/ElectionSummary.aspx |title=nvsos.gov |publisher=nvsos.gov |date=2006-09-08 |accessdate=2013-04-02}} In 2008, Beers was defeated for re-election by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Allison Copening]].Schumacher, Geoff [http://www.lvrj.com/opinion/27968059.html "GEOFF SCHUMACHER: Beers is an unfair victim of Democratic dirty tricks"]. ''[[Las Vegas Review Journal]]'', September 7, 2008; retrieved February 12, 2010. Beers sued for defamation, and the Nevada Democratic Party settled out-of-court in 2010.Spillman, Benjamin [http://www.lvrj.com/news/96546989.html "Democrats Settle Lawsuit, ex-senator says"]. ''[[Las Vegas Review Journal]]'', June 17, 2010; retrieved June 16, 2012. He held no further public office until 2012, when Beers was elected to the non-partisan Las Vegas City Council in a nine-way special election to fill the vacant seat of Councilman Steve Wolfson, who had been appointed Clark County District Attorney. He was elected to a full four-year term the next year.{{cn|date=May 2017}} Beers declared in January 2014 that he was running for the Republican nomination to challenge [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Harry Reid]] in the [[United States Senate election in Nevada, 2016|2016 election]]{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/john-l-smith/las-vegas-city-councilman-beers-gets-early-start-against-harry-reid|title=Las Vegas City Councilman Beers gets early start against Harry Reid|publisher=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|last=Smith|first=John L.|date=January 31, 2014|accessdate=April 24, 2014}} but he withdrew in June 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/john-l-smith/las-vegas-city-councilman-bob-beers-drops-bid-us-senate|title=Las Vegas City Councilman Bob Beers drops bid for U.S. Senate|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|last=Smith|first=John L.|accessdate=June 15, 2015}} Beers lost reelection to the Las Vegas City Council in 2017, finishing first in the May 1 primary contest but losing the June 27 runoff to Steve Seroka, with Seroka winning 3,979 to Beers' 3,387 votes.{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Steve_Seroka#cite_note-linkedin-2|title=Steve Seroka|work=[[Ballotpedia]]|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} Beers ran for [[Nevada State Treasurer]] in the [[Nevada elections, 2018|2018 elections]], but lost to [[Zach Conine]].https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/11/07/democrats-snag-most-nevada-constitutional-offices/1921531002/ ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.leg.state.nv.us/73rd/Legislators/Senators/Beers.cfm Nevada State Legislature - Senator Bob Beers] official government website *[http://www.vote-smart.org/bio.php?can_id=22794 Project Vote Smart - Senator Bob Beers (NV)]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} profile *[http://www.beers4nevada.org/ Beers for Nevada] official campaign website {{DEFAULTSORT:Beers, Bob}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Las Vegas City Council members]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Nevada Assembly]] [[Category:Nevada Republicans]] [[Category:Nevada state senators]] [[Category:People from Livermore, California]] [[Category:University of Nevada, Las Vegas alumni]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Brett Gosper''' (born 21 June 1959 in Melbourne, Australia {{citation needed|date=January 2016}}) is CEO of [[World Rugby]] and a former advertising executive and rugby union player.
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Brett Gosper | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image =BrettGosper.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1959|06|21}} | birth_place = Melbourne, Australia | disappeared_date = <!-- {{Disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = London, UK | nationality = Australian | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = Elizabeth Gosper | partner = | children = 3 | parents = [[Kevan Gosper]], Jillian Mary Galwey | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }}
==Early life== Gosper was educated at [[Scotch College, Melbourne]] and [[Monash University]]; Faculties of Law and Economics. {{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==Advertising career== In 1981, Gosper began his advertising career as graduate trainee with [[Ogilvy & Mather]] in Melbourne and Brisbane, Australia. On being offered a place with the Racing Club rugby team in Paris he transferred to Ogilvy & Mather Paris in 1982 where he would become Group Account Director in 1986. {{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}
In 1989 Gosper left Ogilvy & Mather to go on to become Deputy managing director of France's 3rd largest agency BDDP Paris (now [[TBWA]]) in 1992. While at BDDP Gosper led a number of international account wins including [[TAG Heuer]] watches for whom he wrote the concept of their first worldwide campaign "Don't Crack Under Pressure". Gosper led the successful pitch for [[BMW]] in Germany in 1993 which led to him spending a year in Germany launching the BDDP Frankfurt office.<ref>{{cite web|last=Staff |first=Adweek |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/frankfurt-agencies-play-musical-execs-bddps-raid-leaves-dmbb-scrambling-ke |title=Frankfurt Agencies Play 'Musical Execs': BDDP's Raid Leaves DMB&B Scrambling to Keep P&G Satisfied By Rosemarie TotzaueFRANKFURT – BDDP's raid of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles' executive muscle for client BMW has |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1994 Gosper was recruited by Havas to relaunch [[Euro RSCG]]'s struggling entities in London as Chief Executive Officer of newly branded Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper. {{citation needed|date=October 2015}} For almost a decade Gosper led the agency on an industry acclaimed run of new business acquisition that included [[Abbey National]], [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]], [[Bass Brewery]], [[Cadbury]], [[Coca-Cola]]'s Atlanta roster, [[Commission for Racial Equality]], [[Credit Suisse]], [[Evian]], [[Häagen-Dazs]], [[Intel]], [[Microsoft]], [[Philips]] (Gosper was the author of the worldwide brand slogan "Let's Make Things Better"), [[Reckitt Benckiser]] and [[The Independent]].
The rise of Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper to number one in the Campaign Magazine's Business Performance League ensured the agency a Top 10 London agency ranking and several years as finalist in [[Ad Age]]'s International Agency of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.highbeam.com/436953/article-1G1-15880744/euro-rscg-retools-london-office-new-ceo-named |title=Euro RSCG retools London office, new CEO named. (Brett Gosper) (Brief Article) | HighBeam Business: Arrive Prepared |publisher=Business.highbeam.com |date=14 November 1994 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2003, Gosper moved to New York and [[McCann Erickson]] as CEO of their flagship New York office.<ref>{{cite web|author=Glen Mutel |url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/187960/ |title=CLOSE-UP: NEWSMAKER – BRETT GOSPER. Brett Gosper sets out to make his mark on a third continent – Brand Republic News |publisher=Brandrepublic.com |date=15 August 2003 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2004, Gosper was appointed President of [[TBWA]] New York Group (comprising TBWA\Chiat\Day New York, Tequila New York, and Brand Architecture International). Gosper led the successful pitch for the newly merged [[Sprint-Nextel]] business. With billings of $800 million, it was the biggest marketing services pitch that year in the USA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/people-players/tbwa-lures-mccann-exec-head-unit/40904/ |title=TBWA LURES MCCANN EXEC TO HEAD UNIT | People & Players – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=19 August 2004 |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/20/business/the-media-business-advertising-addenda-manager-at-mccann-is-leaving-for-tbwa.html |title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING – ADDENDA; Manager at McCann Is Leaving for TBWA – New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=20 August 2004 |accessdate=29 January 2012 |first=Stuart |last=Elliott}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/room-nearer-top-gets-gosper-tbwa-74377 |title=Room Nearer the Top Gets Gosper to TBWA |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2005, [[McCann Erickson]] re-hired Gosper as President of McCann Erickson USA. During the time of Gosper's leadership at McCann, the agency's new business wins included [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]], [[Staples Inc.|Staples]], [[Smith Barney]], [[Verizon]], [[US Army]], [[Viagra]], [[Lunesta]], [[Weight Watchers]], [[USA Today]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/gospers-second-thoughts-give-him-second-chance-81743 |title=Gosper's Second Thoughts Give Him A Second Chance |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McMains |first=Andrew |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/gosper-rejoin-mccann-president-81666 |title=Gosper to Rejoin McCann as President |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
Back in London since 2007, Gosper became the Chief Executive Officer of McCann Erickson Europe, Middle East and Africa, until March 2011. Gosper was also a member of the McCann Worldgroup Executive Committee, and Board Executive responsible for European-based global accounts including [[L'Oreal]], [[Nestle]], [[Unilever]], [[Sony Ericsson]], [[InterContinental Hotels Group]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Mark Sweney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/02/citynews.advertising |title=Brett Gosper returns to London | Media | MediaGuardian |publisher=Guardian |date= 2 May 2007|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mccannworldgroup.com/2011/03/gustavo-martinez-joins-mccann-worldgroup-as-european-president/ |title=Gustavo Martinez Joins McCann Worldgroup as European President |publisher=McCANN Worldgroup |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
==Rugby career==
===Early club career in Australia===
Gosper begun his first grade rugby career in Melbourne in 1978 with the Melbourne Rugby Union Football Club. {{citation needed|date=October 2015}} In 1979 at the age of 20, Gosper was named captain. In 1980, he represented the State of Victoria against the New Zealand All Blacks.
Gosper moved to Brisbane in 1981 where he joined GPS Old Boys and the Queensland rugby union squad.
===Racing Club de France (1981–1990)===
Gosper left Australia aged 22 when recruited by France's oldest rugby club, the Racing Club de France (now [[Racing 92]]) in Paris, where he played from 1981 to 1990. The team was also famous at the time for wearing pink bow ties in the 1987 and 1990 finals of the French Championship.
===International career===
Gosper played trials for the [[Australia national rugby union team]] tours in 1979 (Argentina) and 1981 (United Kingdom). He represented the Australian Under 21 Rugby Union team in 1980, versus New Zealand at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]].<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t8RYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v5IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3648,3140334&dq=brett+gosper+rugby&hl=en</ref><ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Tp1WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=guYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4596,4932897&dq=brett+gosper+rugby&hl=en</ref>
Gosper represented a French selection ("Séléction Du Manoir") against British [[Barbarian F.C.]] in 1982 at the [[Parc des Princes]].
Gosper was selected by the French [[Barbarian Rugby Club]] to play against the touring All Blacks at La Rochelle in 1986. Gosper was captain of the Italian side at the Monaco Sevens in 1986 at the [[Stade Louis II]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barbarian-rugby-club.com/joueur/Brett-Gosper/218 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408163231/http://barbarian-rugby-club.com/joueur/Brett-Gosper/218 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 April 2016 |title=Brett Gosper – Ils sont Barbarians |publisher=Barbarian Rugby Club |date= |accessdate=29 January 2012 }}</ref>
===Rugby honours=== *Racing Club de France: Best Club Player, 1987. *Melbourne Rugby Football Club: Best Club Player, 1978-1979-1980.
===World Rugby=== In July 2012, Gosper was appointed as the chief executive of the International Rugby Board, now called [[World Rugby]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/18938451|title=Australian Brett Gosper appointed as new IRB chief executive|accessdate=21 July 2012}}</ref>
As CEO, Gosper has overseen Rugby's successful return to the [[Olympic Games]] (after 92 years absence) in Rio in 2016 <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldrugby.org/news/204417?lang=en|title=Game-changing Olympic return draws at least 16.83 million new fans to rugby|accessdate=14 November 2016}}</ref> as well as a record-breaking [[Rugby World Cup]] in England in 2015. With 2.47 million tickets sold and commercial and ticketing revenues in excess of £600 million, the [[2015 Rugby World Cup]] generated over £160 million in total surplus to [[World Rugby]] for reinvestment in the global game. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/rugby/world-rugby-announces-astonishing-record-financial-results-from-2015/news-story/4d77fe529beb11c69ff42fd3efd31df3|title=World Rugby announces astonishing record financial results from 2015|accessdate=16 December 2016}}</ref>
Gosper also led the repositioning and rebranding of the former 'International Rugby Board' to its current name; [[World Rugby]], which was designed to raise the profile of World Rugby's various 15s and 7s tournament assets and properties. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldrugby.org/news/37400?lang=en|title=IRB becomes World Rugby as new brand is launched|accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> The rebranding has contributed to the dramatic increase in World Rugby's social media presence as one of the most extensive and engaged of the Olympic sports federations.
==Personal life== Gosper is the son of International Olympic Committee member and former Vice-President, [[Kevan Gosper]] and brother of Dean Gosper who is a member of the Executive Board of the International Ski Federation (FIS).
He is married with three children. {{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}

{{Orphan|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox restaurant | name = Burger Heaven | logo = | logo_width = | logo_alt = | image = Burger Heaven Lex 62 jeh.JPG | image_width = | image_alt = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = New York City | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = Location in New York City | slogan = | established = {{start date|1943}} | closed = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | current-owner = | chef = | head-chef = | food-type = Burger restaurant | dress-code = | rating = 17 ([[Zagats]]) | street-address = | city = [[New York City]] | county = [[New York County, New York|New York County]] | state = [[New York (state)|New York]] | postcode = | country = United States | coordinates = {{coord|40.75747|-73.97653|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} | seating-capacity = | reservations = | other-locations = | other-information = | website = https://www.burgerheaven.com/ }} [[File:Burger Heaven.jpg|thumb|right|Burger Heaven]]
'''Burger Heaven''' is a [[Family business|family owned]] [[diner]]-style [[Hamburger|burger]] restaurant in [[New York City]], established in 1943.<ref name="60 years" /> It is not to be confused with a separate and unrelated ''Burger Heaven'' restaurant in [[Alberta, Canada|Alberta]] and [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] that was established in 1984 and serves [[poutine]].<ref>[http://www.burgerheaven.ca/aboutus.htm History & Information @ burgerheaven.ca] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416112806/http://www.burgerheaven.ca/aboutus.htm |date=April 16, 2009 }}</ref> __NOTOC__ ==History== The chain started off as ''Beefburger'' on West 57th Street in 1943, but changed to ''Burger Heaven'' in 1974 due to [[trademark]] issues.<ref name="60 years" /> For its 60th birthday in 2003, the chain served 60-cent food, drink and dessert specials.<ref name="60 years">{{cite web |author=Florence Fabricant |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/30/dining/food-stuff-60-is-long-in-years-but-little-in-pennies-a-celebration.html |title=FOOD STUFF; 60 Is Long in Years but Little in Pennies: A Celebration |date=April 30, 2003 |work=New York Times}}</ref> In addition to burgers, [[tuna salad]] is a favorite at the "consistent" chain owned by Evans Cyprus.<ref>{{cite web |author=Samantha Marshall |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-23533963_ITM |title=Steady diet distinguishes chain Over 60 years, Burger Heaven builds market niche through consistency |date=June 9, 2003 |work=Crain's New York Business}}</ref> The family tradition continued with the second generation of Cyprus family members.<ref>{{cite web |author=Lois Smith Brady |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/03/style/weddings-vows-marguerite-cyprus-and-michael-loucas.html |title=WEDDINGS: VOWS; Marguerite Cyprus and Michael Loucas |date=December 3, 2000 |work=New York Times}}</ref>
In 2009 the chain operated six locations in [[Midtown Manhattan]] and the [[Upper East Side]], though in recent years some locations were closed and the number of locations in May 2012 has been reduced to 3.<ref>[http://burgerheaven.com/ Hamburger Heaven] Locations</ref>
Menu offerings at ''Burger Heaven'' include pizza burgers, chili burgers, [[veggie burger]]s, "classic beef burgers" and turkey burgers as well as an array of salads, hot and cold sandwiches such as grilled cheese, tuna melts, triple-deckers, and [[chicken salad]].<ref name="heaven" /> The burgers are served on [[Kaiser roll|kaiser buns]] and the [[Milkshake|milk shakes]] are "paradisiacal".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.timeout.com/restaurants/midtown-east/1465/burger-heaven |title=Restaurants and Bars: Burger Heaven |work=Time Out New York}}</ref> [[New York (magazine)|New York magazine]] describes the decor as "nostalgic 1990s-meets-1950s" noting that:
{{quote|There's something about the bright yellow Formica tables, chrome fixtures, banquettes covered in cobalt vinyl, and light blue cloud-mural ceiling that does seem to bring you closer to that imaginary meat-patty paradise promised by the restaurant's name.<ref name="heaven">{{cite web |author=Andrew Sessa |url=http://nymag.com/listings/restaurant/Burger-Heaven00/ |title=Burger Heaven restaurant profile |work=New York Magazine}}</ref>}}
In 2013, ''[[Zagats]]'' gave it a food rating of 17.<ref>[http://www.zagat.com/r/burger-heaven-manhattan-3 Zagat rating]</ref>

{{Infobox company |name = CHG Healthcare |logo = |type = [[Privately held company]] |predecessor = CompHealth |founder = Therus C. Kolff, MD |area_served = [[Intermountain West]], United States |key_people = Therus C. Kolff, MD
[[Mike Weinholtz]]
([[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]]) |industry = [[Health care|Healthcare]] |homepage = [http://www.chghealthcare.com/ http://www.chghealthcare.com/] |foundation = [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], United States ({{Start date|1979}}) |location_city = [[Midvale, Utah|Midvale]], Utah |location_country = [[United States]] }} '''CHG Healthcare''' was founded in 1979 by Therus C. Kolff, MD to deliver medical care to rural areas of the western [[United States]]. The company is based in [[Holladay, Utah|Midvale, Utah]], though the postal designation of nearby [[Salt Lake City]] is used in its mailing address.{{Cite web|title = Company History|url = http://www.chghealthcare.com/about-us/company-history|website = www.chghealthcare.com|access-date = 2016-01-22}} CHG Healthcare was originally known as CompHealth, and now includes a collection of healthcare-related companies such as CompHealth, Weatherby Healthcare, RNnetwork, Foundation Medical Staffing, and Global Medical Staffing which was purchased in 2016.{{cite web|title=CHG Healthcare expands temporary physicians staffing business|url=http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20160825/NEWS/160829961}} The CHG family of companies is one of the largest providers of healthcare staffing in the United States, with 31% market share in [[locum tenens]] revenue.{{Cite web|url = http://www.staffingindustry.com/Research-Publications/Daily-News/Report-ranks-largest-US-healthcare-staffing-firms-34943|title = Report ranks largest US healthcare staffing firms|date = 2015-08-05|access-date = 2016-01-22|website = Staffing Industry Analysts|publisher = |last = |first = }} Their services also include both temporary and permanent placement of physicians, nurses and allied health professionals. CHG employs over 2,800 people in seven offices located around the United States, doing business in all 50 states.{{Cite web|url = http://www.staffingindustry.com/Research-Publications/Publications/Healthcare-Staffing-Report/July-2-2015/CHG-Healthcare-Services-to-build-new-headquarters|title = CHG Healthcare Services to build new headquarters|date = 2015-06-26|access-date = 2016-01-22|website = Staffing Industry Analysts|publisher = |last = |first = }} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Companies based in Salt Lake County, Utah]] [[Category:Health care companies established in 1979]] [[Category:Health care companies based in Utah]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Utah]] [[Category:Medical outsourcing companies of the United States]]

{{buzzword|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:cVidya}} {{Infobox company | name = cVidya Networks | logo =Image:Cvidya_Logo.png | type = Private | industry = Telecommunication, [[Service (economics)|Services]], [[Consultant|Consulting]], [[Revenue Management]], [[Revenue assurance|Revenue Assurance]], [[Fraud|Fraud Management]], [[Dealership Management System|Dealer management]] | foundation = 2001 | founder = [http://www.cvidya.com/Management.html Alon Aginsky] | num_employees = 300 (2010) | homepage = [http://www.cvidya.com/ www.cvidya.com]}}
'''cVidya Networks''' is a provider of [[big data]] analytics products for [[communications]] and [[Telecommunications service provider|digital service providers]]. cVidya’s market includes business protection and business growth, including [[revenue assurance]], [[fraud]] management, marketing analytics and [[data monetization]]. The company has 300 employees in 18 countries and has over 150 customers. cVidya's investors include [[Battery Ventures]], [[Carmel Ventures]], Hyperion, StageOne, Saints Capital and Plenus.
==History==
cVidya was founded in 2001 by Alon Aginsky in the US and saw projects at [[Telecom Italia]] and [[Bezeq]] within its first years.
Between 2004–2010 cVidya became one of the leading vendors in the [[Revenue assurance|Revenue Assurance]] domain with the MoneyMap product suite, with their entrance into Europe followed closely by LATAM, APAC, North America and Africa.
cVidya’s acquisition of ECtel in 2010 <ref>[http://www.billingworld.com/news/2010/01/cvidya-wraps-ectel-acquisition.aspx cVidya Wraps ECtel Acquisition]. Billingworld.com</ref> was a major milestone for the company. By acquiring the larger, publicly traded company and consolidating their product portfolios cVidya added the FraudView [[fraud]] management product.
In 2011 cVidya adds [[risk management]] product and announced revenue assurance and fraud management [[eLearning]] courses.<ref>[http://www.telecomasia.net/content/cvidya-launches-elearning-education-center?src=related cVidya launches eLearning education center]. TelecomAsia.net</ref> In that same year, [[Gartner]] ranked cVidya as a market leader.<ref>[http://www.billingworld.com/news/2011/04/gartner-puts-cvidya-at-top-of-revenue-assurance-m.aspx Gartner Puts cVidya at Top of Revenue Assurance Market]. Billingworld.com</ref>
In 2013 cVidya added [[big data]] analytics capabilities and a marketing [[analytics]] suite.<ref>[http://www.telcoprofessionals.com/pressreleases/611/c-vidya-launches-powerful-marketi cVidya Launches Powerful Marketing Analytics Suite]. TelcoProfessionals.com</ref>
In January 2016 the company was bought by [[Amdocs]] for 30 million dollars.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/.premium-1.698229 Amdocs Completes Purchase of cVidya]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-amdocs-to-buy-israeli-co-cvidya-for-30-40m-1001079136|title=Amdocs to buy Israeli co cVidya for $30-40m - Globes|website=Globes|language=he|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.text:
'''Cecil Albert "Ces" Blazey''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|CBE|ED|size=85%}} (21 July 1909 – 20 February 1998) was a New Zealand rugby union and athletics administrator. During the controversial [[1981 South Africa rugby union tour of New Zealand|1981 Springbok tour]] he was the NZRFU chairman and spokesman. He has been described as "one of the most outstanding sports administrators New Zealand has seen" and was "regarded internationally as the leading authority on the laws of the game".<ref>{{cite book |author= Ron Palenski |author2= Rod Chester |author3= Neville McMillan |title= The Encyclopaedia of New Zealand Rugby |year=2005 |edition=4th |publisher= Hodder Moa |location=Auckland |page=249|quote= | url= |isbn= }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Born in [[Hastings]], [[Hawke's Bay]], [[New Zealand]] on 21 July 1909, Blazey was educated at [[Christchurch Boys' High School]] and [[University of Canterbury|Canterbury University College]]. He studied part-time towards a Bachelor of Commerce for two years but did not complete the degree, and played senior rugby in the late 1920s and early 1930s for the university club.<ref name="DNZB Blazey">{{DNZB|title=Cecil Albert Blazey|first= Julia|last= Millen|id=5b31|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref>
==Military service== Blazey joined the Territorial Force in 1927 and was commissioned as a 2nd lieutenant in the New Zealand Permanent Army Service Corps. At the outbreak of [[World War II]] he was rejected for overseas service for medical reasons, and instead was initially posted to administrative duties in New Zealand. He was promoted to temporary lieutenant colonel in 1942 and the following year was sent to the Pacific as commander, New Zealand Permanent Army Service Corps for the [[3rd Division (New Zealand)|3rd Division]]. He returned to New Zealand to a posting in the reserve in 1944 and was appointed an [[Order of the British Empire|Officer of the Order of the British Empire (Military Division)]] in 1945.<ref name="DNZB Blazey"/> He also received the [[Efficiency Decoration]].
==Sports administration== He was a member of the New Zealand Universities Rugby Council for 34 years from 1936 to 1949, later chairman and life member. He was first elected to the [[New Zealand Rugby Football Union]] executive in 1957, and became chairman from 1977 until he retired from the board in 1985. He was a delegate to the International Rugby Board from 1964 to 1986 (chairman in 1965, 1972 and 1985), and was on the board’s Laws Committee from 1972 to 1985.
The decision of the NZRFU to invite a South African team to tour New Zealand in [[1981 Springbok Tour|1981]] attracted international criticism, and Blazey was prominent as the NZRFU spokesman. He had been chairman of the [[New Zealand Amateur Athletic Association]] (NZAAA) from 1966, but stood down in 1981 because of the perceived conflict of interest. He was also a member of the [[New Zeealand Olympic and Commonwealth Games Association|New Zealand Olympic and Commonwealth Games Association]] from 1956 to 1980.
In 1990, Blazey was an inaugural inductee into the [[New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzhalloffame.co.nz/Inductees/B/Ces-Blazey.aspx |title=Ces Blazey |website= |publisher=New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame |accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref> He was promoted to [[Order of the British Empire|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[1991 Birthday Honours|1991 Queen's Birthday Honours]], for services to sport, especially rugby.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=52564 |date=15 June 1991 |page=30 |supp=y }}</ref>
==Other activities== Throughout his working life, Blazey was employed by the AMP (insurance) Society. He rose to become New Zealand senior assistant manager, retiring in 1970.<ref name="DNZB Blazey"/>
He also served on various bodies including the National Heart Foundation and the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation programme advisory committee.<ref>{{cite book |author= Lambert, Max |title= Who’s Who in New Zealand |year=1991|edition= 12th |publisher= Reed |location=Auckland |pages=61–62 |quote= | url= |isbn= 0 7900 01306 }}</ref>
==Death== Blazey died in Wellington in 1998<ref name="DNZB Blazey"/> and his ashes were buried at [[Karori Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://wellington.govt.nz/services/community-and-culture/cemeteries/cemeteries-search/details?id=66526&serviceType=Cremation |title=Cemeteries search (cremation) |website= |publisher=Wellington City Council |accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://wellington.govt.nz/services/community-and-culture/cemeteries/cemeteries-search/details?id=93601&serviceType=Burial |title=Cemeteries search (burial) |website= |publisher=Wellington City Council |accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}

revision.text:
A '''Design brief''' is a document for a [[design]] project developed by a person or team (the 'designer' or 'design team') in consultation with the 'client'. They outline the deliverables and scope of the project including any products or works (function and aesthetics), timing and budget. They can be used for many projects including those in the fields of architecture, interior design and industrial design. Design briefs are also used to evaluate the effectiveness of a design after it has been produced and during the creation process to keep the project on track and on budget. Some firms rely on them more than others but there is a move towards greater accountability in the design process and thus many people find them most useful. They usually change over time and are adjusted as the project scope evolves. Often they are 'signed off' by the client and designer at set stages in the project.
A design brief may use the following layout: # Title page # Table of #* Past Accomplishments # [[Problem Statement]] #* Problem Description #* Constraints #* [[Budget]] #* Time #* Needs of the Problem # [[Goal]]s #* What you plan to accomplish #** Due dates # Solution Analysis #* [[Risks]]/[[Economics|Benefits]] #* Planned Solutions #* [[Sketch (drawing)|Sketches]] # Synopsis #* Evaluation #* Conclusion/Summary
==See also== * [[Creative brief]] * [[Product design specification]], a document that describes design specifications
==External links== * [http://www.cleardesignuk.com/design-brief.html Advice about writing design briefs] * [http://project-brief.casual.pm Design Brief examples, templates and video guides]
{{Design}}
[[Category:Design]] [[Category:Product development]]
